headline.main: Much Ado About 'Mandatory' Turkish Health Insurance

docs.abstract: Americans in Turkey can relax. After a flurry of inquiries about how to sign up with the Turkish social security authorities for "mandatory" health insurance, it turns out a new law does not require health coverage after all.
docs.snippet: Americans in Turkey can relax. After a flurry of inquiries about how to sign up with the Turkish social security authorities for "mandatory" health insurance, it turns out a new law does not require health coverage after all.

headline.main: Determining the Level of Payments in Health Care

docs.abstract: Reasonable people may differ on how best to set fees paid to health-care providers, but it is beyond dispute that the current system is inefficient and far too costly, an economist writes.
docs.snippet: Reasonable people may differ on how best to set fees paid to health-care providers, but it is beyond dispute that the current system is inefficient and far too costly, an economist writes.

docs.lead_paragraph: Over all, 63 percent of Americans said they supported the new federal requirement that private health insurance plans cover the cost of birth control.

headline.seo: Americans Divided on Birth Control Coverage, Poll Finds
headline.main: Poll Finds Wide Support for Birth Control Coverage
headline.print_headline: Poll Finds Divisions Over Requiring Coverage

docs.abstract: Close divide in a Senate vote over whether employers can refuse insurance coverage for contraception mirrors a sharp partisan divide among the public; polls show that 63 percent of Americans support the new federal requirement that private health insurance plans cover the cost of birth control; many of those polled also express impatience with the focus on women's reproductive issues in an era of economic distress.
docs.snippet: Over all, 63 percent of Americans said they supported the new federal requirement that private health insurance plans cover the cost of birth control.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Robbie Brown and Kim Severson in Atlanta, Steven Yaccino in Chicago, Malia Wollan in San Francisco, Ian Lovett in Los Angeles and Dan Frosch in Denver.

docs.lead_paragraph: Republicans failed in their attempt to deny free access to preventive care, but may just be helping to inform more Americans about the benefits of health reform.
docs.abstract: Editorial welcomes defeat of Republican-backed Senate measure that would have crippled the expansion of preventative health care in America; notes amendment would have allowed any employer or insurance company to refuse coverage for any activity to which they claim a religious or moral objection; suggests Republicans, by supporting measure, may help inform more people about the popular benefits of health care reform and about the extremism of the party that seems determined to take them away.
docs.snippet: Republicans failed in their attempt to deny free access to preventive care, but may just be helping to inform more Americans about the benefits of health reform.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: A growing number of baby boomers are venturing into old age on their own, a shift that is changing the traditional portrait of older Americans.

headline.seo: More Americans Rejecting Marriage in 50s and Beyond
headline.main: More Americans Rejecting Marriage in 50s and Beyond
headline.print_headline: More Americans Rejecting Marriage In 50s and Beyond

docs.abstract: Divorce rate among baby boomers has surged by more than 50 percent, even as divorce rates over all have stabilized nationally, indicating that more people in their 50s and 60s are choosing to venture into old age on their own; trend is likely to change the traditional portrait of old age in America, and transform the way the elderly are cared for, shifting much of the economic burden to federal and local governments.
docs.snippet: A growing number of baby boomers are venturing into old age on their own, a shift that is changing the traditional portrait of older Americans.

docs.lead_paragraph: Maybe it is time to recognize that law alone is not enough to effect social change.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by public interest lawyer Louise G Trubek questions why Americans are still arguing about woman's ability to control her own fertility; notes Supreme Court struck down state restrictions on contraception nearly 50 years ago because they violated a right to privacy; calls for more social activism on behalf of women's rights.
docs.snippet: Maybe it is time to recognize that law alone is not enough to effect social change.

docs.lead_paragraph: The presidential candidate would cut taxes for almost everybody and everything — except, it seems, for single mothers, soldiers and municipal bond investors.
docs.abstract: Floyd Norris High & Low Finance column contends 2012 presidential campaign has been the worst for election-year tax rhetoric than any he can remember; points out the most amazing proposal came from Rick Santorum, who would cut taxes for almost everybody and everything--except, it seems, for single mothers, soldiers and municipal bond investors; posits that no matter how much talk there is about cutting spending, the government needs to raise more revenue than it is getting now to finance needed operations while reducing benefits.
docs.snippet: The presidential candidate would cut taxes for almost everybody and everything — except, it seems, for single mothers, soldiers and municipal bond investors.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate killed an effort to let employers and health insurance companies deny coverage for services they object to on religious or moral grounds.

headline.seo: Birth Control Coverage Measure Defeated in Senate
headline.main: Senate Rejects Step Targeting Coverage of Contraception

docs.abstract: Senate upholds President Barack Obama's birth control policy, voting to kill a Republican effort to let employers and health insurance companies deny coverage for contraceptives and other items they object to on religious or moral grounds; vote illustrates sharp divide between the parties.
docs.snippet: The Senate killed an effort to let employers and health insurance companies deny coverage for services they object to on religious or moral grounds.

docs.lead_paragraph: Even before a tornado tore through this small southern Illinois city, killing six people, Harrisburg had seen trouble. And they have had to rebuild, over and over.

headline.seo: Southern Illinois Town Is All Too Versed in Taking a Hit
headline.main: Illinois Town All Too Versed in Taking a Hit
headline.print_headline: Town in Illinois All Too Versed In Taking a Hit

docs.abstract: Harrisburg, Ill, will have to rebuild yet again after tornado tears through, killing six people, and leaving others cowering inside closets, huddling under mattresses showered with glass, metal and wood, and hiding inside bathtubs; community has been recovering from floods and ice storms and now residents have a new hurdle to overcome.
docs.snippet: Even before a tornado tore through this small southern Illinois city, killing six people, Harrisburg had seen trouble. And they have had to rebuild, over and over.

byline.contributor: Emma G. Fitzsimmons contributed reporting from New York.

docs.lead_paragraph: 9:25 p.m. | Updated ALBANY- One resident wanted the governor's opinion on the state of kayaking regulation. Another wanted to chat about train service in Stony Brook. A Monty Python fan even asked the governor, ''What is the airspeed velocity of an unladen swallow?''

headline.main: The Governor Will Now Take Questions. Except That One, or That One ...

docs.abstract: Questions that New York Gov Andrew M Cuomo chose to ignore in an online chat with state residents, like those about hydrofracking, provide a glimpse behind the curtain of the Web chat that demonstrates how an elected official can smooth the rough and random edges of public discourse. (M)
